events.description: Silver prices experienced extreme swings, rising 3% after a 10% plunge.

events.event_name: Nomination of Kevin Warsh as Fed chair
events.description: The nomination of Kevin Warsh to lead the US Federal Reserve.
Silver reached a record high peak in late January.

facts.fact_text: Silver rose more than 3% to above $73 per ounce on Friday after a 10% plunge.

evidences.evidence_text: Silver rose more than 3% to above $73 per ounce on Friday after plunging nearly 10% earlier in the session

facts.fact_text: Silver volatility reached levels not seen since 1980.

evidences.evidence_text: volatility surging to levels last seen in 1980

facts.fact_text: Silver remains approximately 40% below its January 29 peak.

evidences.evidence_text: remains about 40% below its Jan. 29 peak

facts.fact_text: Kevin Warsh has been nominated as the next Fed chair.

evidences.evidence_text: nomination of Kevin Warsh as the next Fed chair

claims.claim_text: Silver's extreme price swings are caused by its small market size and thin liquidity.

evidences.evidence_text: reflecting silver’s smaller market size, thinner liquidity, and heavy speculative positioning

claims.claim_text: Speculative buying from Chinese traders added unsustainable froth to the silver rally.

evidences.evidence_text: Speculative buying, particularly from Chinese traders, added froth to the rally

claims.claim_text: Kevin Warsh is considered a hawkish choice for Federal Reserve chair.
claims.author: Market participants

evidences.evidence_text: widely seen as the more hawkish choice

claims.claim_text: Concerns over Fed independence boosted demand for safe-haven assets.

evidences.evidence_text: concerns over the US Federal Reserve’s independence that boosted safe-haven demand

evidence.evidence_text: a sharp rebound in the dollar following the nomination of Kevin Warsh
Pressure on precious metals intensified further after a sharp rebound in the dollar
heightened geopolitical risks... boosted safe-haven demand
Price swings in the metal have been far more extreme than in gold, reflecting silver’s smaller market size, thinner liquidity
